episodes.title: Surprising Truths About Smear Campaigns: Structure, Membership, Dynamics
episodes.description:
When targeted, narcissists and psychopaths relish smear campaigns because these provide them with attention, excitement and thrills; justify their grandiose paranoid ideation; legitimize their aggression; and affirm their victimhood. They do not experience shame, remorse, intimidation, chastisement, or fear (even if they pretend otherwise), but rage and elation.

Truth can also be a smear campaign when taken out of context (decontextualized)

Form of gangstalking, narrative role-reversal (victimhood)

Example of smear campaign instigator triadic dynamics:

Smear campaigns involve pathetic losers. 

Psychopathic cult leader masquerading as a benevolent guru: self-righteous moralizing to disguise the projection. The inducer. Unable to maintain long-term relationships, especially with intimate partners. Substance user.

Faded bloated past their prime histrionic, failed wannabe impostor, pretending to be an investigative journalist, expert, or researcher to lend an air of faux professionalism and objectivity to her or his pursuit of narcissistic supply and celebrity. Sublimates her paranoia as a form of ostentatious faux courage. The exploiter. Could be more than one.

Eternal cult member with a cult mind to blindly follow orders down the cult leader’s rabbit hole in return for a sense of belonging to an extended family, friendship, intimacy, and being accepted warts, shortcomings, repulsiveness, and all. The slave. Could be more than one.

The shapeshifting triumvirate recruits people with grievances, real or imagined, to do their bidding and act as cannon fodder or flying monkeys. 

Proselytizers vs. Disseminators: canonical text, exegesis and deconstruction, embellishments 

All smear campaigns are conspiracy theories. Narrative themes of smear campaign are folkloric: sexual abuse, fraud, malice, comeuppance, morality play of good vs. evil.

Cultlike dynamics (for me or against me, friend or foe, chosen few, privileged information and arcane knowledge)

Inducer in shared psychosis and narcissist in shared fantasy

Preemptive epistemic injury (real victim disbelieved): victim confused, isolated, questions own sanity and reality

Creating unsafe environment

Involved mentally disturbed people, self-enhancement, defense against ego-dystonic shame and guilt, loss, and nuance

Rescuer-savior, crusader complex

Splitting, self-splitting, and projection (of both traits and actions), reaction formation

Harvesting sympathy, allegiance, loyalty, commitment, validation, soothing, empowerment

Externalized aggression (e.g., revenge for shaming humiliation, esp. in public), virulent envy

episodes.title: Why Narcissist Feels Entitled to Magical, Enchanted Life
episodes.description:
The Uses of Enchantment: The Meaning and Importance of Fairy Tales

Narcissists feels entitled to magical, enchanted life in which the impossible happens time and again, effortlessly and unexpectedly. Fairy tale or movie that unfold inexorably in accordance with some internal logic. 

Enchant the pedestrian and sources of disenchantment/reality. Disenchantment feels like defeat, a trap, suffocating and stifling 

Magical thinking

Addicted to Surprises: universe smiles on him/her, proof of love, care; adrenaline and dopamine rushes (thrill-seeking)

Enchantment is recreation of maternal safe base

Disenchantment: boredom, envy, anger, other negative affects

Coercive enchantment: shared fantasy, crime, dramatic antics, enchanted instability and unpredictability, recklessness 

Escapism as enchantment: substance use, cults, video games, the online world (cybersphere), exclusionary ideologies, antagonistic conflict, nihilism, instrumentalizing, idealization and idolizing, erotomania and other narrative delusions, cognitive distortions and biases

Manic schemes

Media exposure (celebrity) even via antisocial, defiant, or contumacious acts 

Consumption

If all else fails: delusional self-enchantment via self-enhancement of self-concept (false self) and self-supply

episodes.title: Wikipedia: Narcissistic Cult, Cabal
episodes.description:
AI chatbots have begun to warn people about the unreliability of Wikipedia. 

In the English Wikipedia, there are only 500 active editors out of 50,000,000 users. It is no longer a “CROWDsourced” resource, but a closed, delusional, fantasy-prone cult, a shared fantasy. 

Shocking admission by a top Wikipedian is representative of the ethos. Slp1: “I tend to edit articles that take my fancy and have no connection to my professional and academic background.” Wikipedia "editor" slp1 ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User:Slp1 ). And she is PROUD of it!

Wikipedia is a cult with cult leaders and arcane, obscure, deliberately obfuscating language and procedures, far more cumbersome than any university, research lab protocols, or peer-reviewed journal. Wikipedia has become an exclusionary and xenophobic in-group.

episodes.title: Narcissist's 10 Commandments, Godly Injunctions to You
episodes.description:
Narcissism is a primitive religion and the narcissist is its implacable deity which demands human sacrifice. 

The messages of the narcissist are religious and missionary.

The narcissist's Ten Commandments: 

You will acknowledge my superiority, uniqueness, and perfection and you will dwell in the promised land of the shared fantasy

My speech and conduct are beyond reproach and never to be doubted, challenged, or criticized. I am the yardstick of all that is just and true, the sole giver of the Law, your absolute master. 

You are my creation, you exist only through me and in me, you will never deviate, divert, contradict, or challenge who I made you to be

I mediate between you and reality, nothing is veritable until I decree it and make it so

I am your entire world, you need no one else but me

Serving and adulating me elevates and improves you, makes you a better, self-actualized version of yourself

I expect your unconditional love and unalloyed devotion even when you are tested and are called to sacrifice yourself 

You will fear my punishment and retribution if you were to break any of these commandments. You will avoid all situations, circumstances, and environments which may lead you astray. 

You are the sinner and I am the redeemer: whatever goes wrong is your fault; I am your savior, rescuer, healer, fixer, and protector

Never deviate from these commandments and you will have a happy life. Do not doubt, overthink, analyze, or criticize. Submit.

You are welcome to my FREE seminar: “Scientific Healing and Recovery from Narcissistic Abuse: Evidence-based Practices (clinical and self-help)”.

Click on this link for details:

https://vrfoundation.net/thank-you-south-east-european-university-seeu-and-commonwealth-institute-for-advanced-professional-studies-ciaps/

See you there!

Sam Vaknin

episodes.title: Did the Narcissist Hypnotize You? (Compilation)
Dynamics, Grief in Relationships with Narcissists, Cluster B (Zagreb Seminar, Part 4 of 5)
episodes.description:
At first, the narcissist or borderline idealizes you. Then comes the ineluctable devaluation and discard, followed by the most profound grief you have ever experienced.

The field of personality disorders is at an impasse, reflected in the competing diagnostic models in the DSM 5-TR (the categorical lists of diagnostic criteria imported verbatim from the DSM-IV-TR vs. the dimensional, descriptive alternative models, relegated to the appendices). We need to reconceive of cluster B personality disorders as posttraumatic dissociative conditions involving self-states (subpersonalities with pseudoidentities). 

This seems to be the most clinically rigorous way to rid ourselves of excessive comorbidities and polythetic diagnoses. Recasting cluster B personality disorders as post-traumatic conditions which involve dissociation goes a long way towards resolving these outstanding conundrums and provides for hitherto absent efficacious treatment modalities. 

Clinicians Seminar in Zagreb, December 8, 2024, Organized by Snaga Namjere https://snaganamjere.com/

episodes.title: Flying Monkey Psychology in Narcissist’s Shared Fantasy
episodes.description:
With the flying monkey, the narcissist creates an attenuated cult-like shared fantasy. 

The narcissist is the flying monkey’s role model. But the flying monkey also serves as savior-rescuer and maternal protective figure. 

Narcissist devalues, discards, and punishes vicariously, by proxy, through the agency of the flying monkey, the narcissist’s long arm, an extension of his omnipotence. Flying monkeys, therefore, buttress the narcissist’s grandiosity.
 
The flying monkey experiences the shared fantasy the way an intimate partner does: feel chosen, unique, omnipotent, in the know, thrilled/excited/aroused, useful (needed), legitimized.

Reactive (mortification)

Type (cerebral to somatic, overt to covert or schizoid)

Switching between self-states: borderline, primary psychopath

Individuates internally, via switching

Switching between internalized and externalized aggression

Role of dissociation

Narcissistic alignment is when narcissists choose a narcissist – contemporary, historical, or fictitious character - as a role model to be emulated.

Some signs of switching: Talkativity (hyper-verbalizing), hyperreflexivity (pseudo-psychosis) and HYPERACTIVITY followed by a period of subdued, slow motion, hesitant reactivity.

episodes.title: Your Role, Punishment in Narcissist’s Narrative
episodes.description:
People with a disorganized erratic cluster B personality disorder create simultaneous but mutually exclusive narratives of their lives intended to manage dissonance, both internal and external (with reality). These narratives are the equivalents of self-states or “multiple” personalities (subpersonalities).

Examples of such narratives: I am normal, I have a loving family, I am promiscuous, I am a psychopath. 

When these narratives collapse, the disordered person allocates them to his/her nearest and dearest as if these were theatre productions or movies (e.g., the narcissist’s shared fantasy). The role of these actors is to validate the reality of the narratives (the same function of narcissistic supply in NPD). 

The actors dissociate (depersonalize and derealize) within the fantasy. 
Because these actors are misperceived as internal objects, offloading the narratives onto them unburdens the disordered person. The actions of the actors or agents are owned by the disordered person without the attendant risks or adverse consequences.

When the actors regain independence, agency, and personal autonomy, they become persecutory objects and the disordered person experiences narcissistic mortification. 

The disordered person attempts to hoover them or to co-opt anyone new in their lives. Should this strategy fail, they try to destroy the frustrating objects.

episodes.title: Prosocial (Communal) Malignant Narcissist
episodes.description:
3 Types of Malignant Narcissist: Grandiose, Covert, Borderline parallels high-functioning, prosocial/communal, and low-functioning. 

Low-functioning malignant narcissist utterly dysfunctional while high-functioning malignant narcissist professionally functional and interpersonally dysfunctional. 

In low-functioning (borderline) malignant narcissist, human contact of any kind - from shopping to dating - triggers sadism, justified by grandiose contempt and haughtiness. The cumulative adverse outcomes are such that the malignant narcissist gradually drifts towards withdrawal and avoidance (schizoid behaviors) as a way to preserve ego syntony via alloplastic defenses ("I should waste my precious time and towering intellect"). 

Prosocial (Communal) Narcissist able to function professionally and interpersonally within an in-group. Directs his psychopathy and sadism exclusively at the out-group. Always charismatic leader. 

LITERATURE

WATCH 3 Types of Malignant Narcissist: Grandiose, Covert, Borderline https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V2fJK9sylhU

WATCH Malignant Covert Narcissist Becomes Primary Psychopath to Compensate for Collapse https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FlaDDwzJG-E

Otto F. Kernberg (2020) Malignant Narcissism and Large Group Regression, The Psychoanalytic Quarterly, 89:1, 1-24, January 2020
DOI: 10.1080/00332828.2020.1685342 (https://doi.org/10.1080/00332828.2020.1685342)

episodes.title: Hatebombing: Malignant Narcissist’s Inverted Shared Fantasy
episodes.description:
Locus of grandiosity of malignant (psychopathic) and sadistic narcissists is their invulnerability, unemotionality, flat attachment, rigidity, and heartless cruelty (disguised as altruism, if prosocial).

They are transactional:

To the narcissist, all people are useful tools (in both senses of the word) or collateral damage. The impact the narcissist is having on people’s lives, for better or for worse, is a mere by-product or a side effect of his/her pursuit of grandiosity-affirming narcissistic, sadistic, or self-supply. 

Do you care about me? Narcissist: I do. You are useful to me. But, don’t you have emotions for me? N: I don’t do emotions. I do relationship maintenance. I do business: give and take. So, why stay in touch? N: I owe you. I repay my debts. Plus, you could still be useful. 

Their shared fantasy is inverted; they start with hatebombing, devaluation and discard (the whole point of the fantasy), mixed with negative idealization (mythological demonization). So, their fantasies are extremely short, nasty, and brutal.

In rare cases, when the potential partner is also a malignant or sadistic narcissist, they become codependent or borderline, though still manifesting dysregulated abuse and coercive behaviors. 

In such inverted shared fantasies, they transition to the role of a victim, letting the counterparty initiate the separation by betraying them (betrayal fantasy).

episodes.title: Narcissism, the New Faith - Part 2: Missionary Cult and the End of Society
episodes.description:
FIRST PART Narcissism, the New Faith - Part 1: Distributed God and Human Sacrifice  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b87WQj3q0_w

Pathological narcissism is the abused child's personal religion, with the False Self as the godhead. The child sacrifices his true self to the false self in return for the latter's grandiose fantasies and defelection of the pain and hurt suffered by the traumatized child. The narcissist then proceeds to extract narcissistic supply from other people in order to validate the reality of the False Self: he acts like a missionary trying to convert his sources of supply into his private religion or cult. As more people became narcissists, narcissism turned into an organizing and explanatory principle of human societies everywhere, imbuing the narcissists' life with meaning and prescribing or proscribing behavior and technological progress. Narcissism is the newest faith and its godhead is a distributed, network deity with each node in the network - each narcissist - a god unto himself.

(From the book "Malignant Self-love: Narcissism Revisited" by Sam Vaknin - Click on this link to purchase the print book, or 16 e-books, or 3 DVDs with 16 hours of video lectures on narcissists, psychopaths, and abuse in relationships: http://www.narcissistic-abuse.com/thebook.html)

episodes.title: Narcissist's Cult
episodes.description:
Everything You Need to Know about Narcissists, Psychopaths, and Abuse - click on this link: http://www.narcissistic-abuse.com/faq1.html

The narcissist is the guru at the centre of a cult. Like other gurus, he demands complete obedience from his flock: his spouse, his offspring, other family members, friends, and colleagues. He feels entitled to adulation and special treatment by his followers. He punishes the wayward and the straying lambs. He enforces discipline, adherence to his teachings, and common goals. The less accomplished he is in reality -- the more stringent his mastery and the more pervasive the brainwashing. (From the book "Malignant Self-love: Narcissism Revisited" by Sam Vaknin - Click on this link to purchase the print book, or 16 e-books, or 2 DVDs with 12 hours of video lectures on narcissists, psychopaths, and abuse in relationships: http://www.narcissistic-abuse.com/thebook.html)
